trans-unit.source: Table partitions in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Table partitions in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for using table partitions in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for using table partitions in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: To migrate SQL Server partition definitions to SQL Data Warehouse:
trans-unit.target: To migrate SQL Server partition definitions to SQL Data Warehouse:

trans-unit.source: Remove SQL Server partition functions and schemes since this is managed for you when you create the table.
trans-unit.target: Remove SQL Server partition functions and schemes since this is managed for you when you create the table.

trans-unit.source: Define the partitions when you create the table.
trans-unit.target: Define the partitions when you create the table.

trans-unit.source: Simply specify partition boundary points and whether you want the boundary point to be effective RANGE RIGHT or RANGE LEFT.
trans-unit.target: Simply specify partition boundary points and whether you want the boundary point to be effective RANGE RIGHT or RANGE LEFT.

trans-unit.source: SQL DW offers a DBA several choices for table types: heap, clustered index (CI), and clustered column-store index (CCI).
trans-unit.target: SQL DW offers a DBA several choices for table types: heap, clustered index (CI), and clustered column-store index (CCI).

trans-unit.source: For each of these table types, the DBA can also partition the table, which means dividing it into multiple sections to improve performance.
trans-unit.target: For each of these table types, the DBA can also partition the table, which means dividing it into multiple sections to improve performance.

trans-unit.source: However, creating a table with too many partitions can actually cause performance degradations or query failures under some circumstances.
trans-unit.target: However, creating a table with too many partitions can actually cause performance degradations or query failures under some circumstances.

trans-unit.source: These concerns are especially true for CCI tables.
trans-unit.target: These concerns are especially true for CCI tables.

trans-unit.source: For partitioning to be helpful, it is important for a DBA to understand when to use partitioning and the number of partitions to create.
trans-unit.target: For partitioning to be helpful, it is important for a DBA to understand when to use partitioning and the number of partitions to create.

trans-unit.source: These guidelines are intended to help DBAs make the best choices for their scenarios.
trans-unit.target: These guidelines are intended to help DBAs make the best choices for their scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Normally table partitions are useful in two primary ways:
trans-unit.target: Normally table partitions are useful in two primary ways:

trans-unit.source: Using partition switching to quickly truncate a section of a table.
trans-unit.target: Using partition switching to quickly truncate a section of a table.

trans-unit.source: A commonly used design is for a fact table to contain rows only for some predetermined finite period.
trans-unit.target: A commonly used design is for a fact table to contain rows only for some predetermined finite period.

trans-unit.source: For example, a sales fact table might contain data only for the past 36 months.
trans-unit.target: For example, a sales fact table might contain data only for the past 36 months.

trans-unit.source: At the end of every month, the oldest month of sales data is deleted from the table.
trans-unit.target: At the end of every month, the oldest month of sales data is deleted from the table.

trans-unit.source: This could be accomplished by simply deleting all of the rows for the oldest month, but deleting a large amount of data row-by-row can take a very long time.
trans-unit.target: This could be accomplished by simply deleting all of the rows for the oldest month, but deleting a large amount of data row-by-row can take a very long time.

trans-unit.source: To optimize for this scenario, SQL DW supports partition swapping, which enables the entire set of rows in a partition to be dropped in a single fast operation.
trans-unit.target: To optimize for this scenario, SQL DW supports partition swapping, which enables the entire set of rows in a partition to be dropped in a single fast operation.

trans-unit.source: Partitioning enables queries to easily exclude processing a large set of rows (i.e. a partition) if queries place a predicate on the partitioning column.
trans-unit.target: Partitioning enables queries to easily exclude processing a large set of rows (i.e. a partition) if queries place a predicate on the partitioning column.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the sales fact table is partitioned into 36 months using the sales date field, then queries that filter on the sale date can skip processing partitions that don’t match the filter.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the sales fact table is partitioned into 36 months using the sales date field, then queries that filter on the sale date can skip processing partitions that don’t match the filter.

trans-unit.source: In effect, partitioning used in this way is a coarse grained index.
trans-unit.target: In effect, partitioning used in this way is a coarse grained index.

trans-unit.source: When creating clustered column-store indexes in SQL DW, a DBA needs to consider an additional factor: number of row. CCI tables can achieve a high degree of compression and helps SQL DW accelerate query performance. Due to how compression works internally in SQL DW, each partition in a CCI table needs to have a fairly large number of rows before data is compressed. In addition, SQL DW spreads data across a large number of distributions, and each distribution is further divided by partitions. For optimal compression and performance, a minimum of 100,000 rows per distribution & partition is needed. Using the example above, if the sales fact table contained 36 monthly partitions, and given that SQL DW has 60 distributions, then the sales fact table should contain 6 million rows per month, or 216 million rows when all months are populated. If a table contains significantly less rows than the recommended minimum, then the DBA should consider creating the table with fewer partitions in order to make the number of rows per distribution larger.
trans-unit.target: When creating clustered column-store indexes in SQL DW, a DBA needs to consider an additional factor: number of row. CCI tables can achieve a high degree of compression and helps SQL DW accelerate query performance. Due to how compression works internally in SQL DW, each partition in a CCI table needs to have a fairly large number of rows before data is compressed. In addition, SQL DW spreads data across a large number of distributions, and each distribution is further divided by partitions. For optimal compression and performance, a minimum of 100,000 rows per distribution & partition is needed. Using the example above, if the sales fact table contained 36 monthly partitions, and given that SQL DW has 60 distributions, then the sales fact table should contain 6 million rows per month, or 216 million rows when all months are populated. If a table contains significantly less rows than the recommended minimum, then the DBA should consider creating the table with fewer partitions in order to make the number of rows per distribution larger.

trans-unit.source: To size your current database at the partition level use a query like the one below:
trans-unit.target: To size your current database at the partition level use a query like the one below:

trans-unit.source: The total number of distributions equals the number of storage locations used when we create a table.
trans-unit.target: The total number of distributions equals the number of storage locations used when we create a table.

trans-unit.source: That's a complex way of saying that each table is created once per distribution.
trans-unit.target: That's a complex way of saying that each table is created once per distribution.

trans-unit.source: You can also anticipate roughly how many rows, and therefore how big, each partition will be.
trans-unit.target: You can also anticipate roughly how many rows, and therefore how big, each partition will be.

trans-unit.source: The partition in the source data warehouse will be subdivided into each distribution.
trans-unit.target: The partition in the source data warehouse will be subdivided into each distribution.

trans-unit.source: Use the following calculation to guide you when determining your partition size:
trans-unit.target: Use the following calculation to guide you when determining your partition size:

trans-unit.source: MPP Partition Size = SMP Partition Size / Number of Distributions
trans-unit.target: MPP Partition Size = SMP Partition Size / Number of Distributions

trans-unit.source: You can find out how many distributions your SQL Data Warehouse database has using the following query:
trans-unit.target: You can find out how many distributions your SQL Data Warehouse database has using the following query:

trans-unit.source: Now you know how big each partition is in the source system and what size you are anticipating for SQLDW you can decide on your partition boundary.
trans-unit.target: Now you know how big each partition is in the source system and what size you are anticipating for SQLDW you can decide on your partition boundary.

trans-unit.source: One final piece of information you need to factor in to the table partition decision is workload management.
trans-unit.target: One final piece of information you need to factor in to the table partition decision is workload management.

trans-unit.source: In SQL Data Warehouse the maximum memory allocated to each distribution during query execution is governed by this feature.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Data Warehouse the maximum memory allocated to each distribution during query execution is governed by this feature.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to the following article for more details on [workload management].
trans-unit.target: Please refer to the following article for more details on [workload management].

trans-unit.source: Ideally your partition will be sized with inmemory operations such as columnstore index rebuilds in mind.
trans-unit.target: Ideally your partition will be sized with inmemory operations such as columnstore index rebuilds in mind.

trans-unit.source: An index rebuild is a memory intensive operation.
trans-unit.target: An index rebuild is a memory intensive operation.

trans-unit.source: Therefore you will want to ensure that the partition index rebuild is not starved of memory.
trans-unit.target: Therefore you will want to ensure that the partition index rebuild is not starved of memory.

trans-unit.source: Increasing the amount of memory available to your query can be achieved by switching from the default role to one of the other roles available.
trans-unit.target: Increasing the amount of memory available to your query can be achieved by switching from the default role to one of the other roles available.

trans-unit.source: Information on the allocation of memory per distribution is available by querying the resource governor dynamic management views.
trans-unit.target: Information on the allocation of memory per distribution is available by querying the resource governor dynamic management views.

trans-unit.source: In reality your memory grant will be less than the figures below.
trans-unit.target: In reality your memory grant will be less than the figures below.

trans-unit.source: However, this provides a level of guidance that you can use when sizing your partitions for data management operations.
trans-unit.target: However, this provides a level of guidance that you can use when sizing your partitions for data management operations.

trans-unit.source: Try to avoid sizing your partitions beyond the memory grant provided by the extra large resource class.
trans-unit.target: Try to avoid sizing your partitions beyond the memory grant provided by the extra large resource class.

trans-unit.source: If your partitions grow beyond this figure you run the risk of memory pressure which in turn leads to less optimal compression.
trans-unit.target: If your partitions grow beyond this figure you run the risk of memory pressure which in turn leads to less optimal compression.

trans-unit.source: To switch partitions between two tables you must ensure that the partitions align on their respective boundaries and that the table definitions match.
trans-unit.target: To switch partitions between two tables you must ensure that the partitions align on their respective boundaries and that the table definitions match.

trans-unit.source: As check constraints are not available to enforce the range of values in a table the source table must contain the same partition boundaries as the target table.
trans-unit.target: As check constraints are not available to enforce the range of values in a table the source table must contain the same partition boundaries as the target table.

trans-unit.source: If this is not the case then the parition switch will fail as the partition metadata will not be synchronised.
trans-unit.target: If this is not the case then the parition switch will fail as the partition metadata will not be synchronised.

trans-unit.source: The most efficient method to split a partition that already contains data is to use a CTAS statement.
trans-unit.target: The most efficient method to split a partition that already contains data is to use a CTAS statement.

trans-unit.source: If the partitioned table is a clustered columnstore then the table partition must be empty before it can be split.
trans-unit.target: If the partitioned table is a clustered columnstore then the table partition must be empty before it can be split.

trans-unit.source: Below is a sample partitioned columnstore table containing one row in the final partition:
trans-unit.target: Below is a sample partitioned columnstore table containing one row in the final partition:

trans-unit.source: By Creating the statistic object we ensure that table metadata is more accurate.
trans-unit.target: By Creating the statistic object we ensure that table metadata is more accurate.

trans-unit.source: If we omit creating statistics then SQL Data Warehouse will use default values.
trans-unit.target: If we omit creating statistics then SQL Data Warehouse will use default values.

trans-unit.source: For details on statistics please review <linkText>statistics</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details on statistics please review <linkText>statistics</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We can then query for the row count leveraging the sys.partitions catalog view:
trans-unit.target: We can then query for the row count leveraging the sys.partitions catalog view:

trans-unit.source: If we try to split this table we will get an error:
trans-unit.target: If we try to split this table we will get an error:

trans-unit.source: Msg 35346, Level 15, State 1, Line 44 SPLIT clause of ALTER PARTITION statement failed because the partition is not empty.
trans-unit.target: Msg 35346, Level 15, State 1, Line 44 SPLIT clause of ALTER PARTITION statement failed because the partition is not empty.

trans-unit.source: Only empty partitions can be split in when a columnstore index exists on the table.
trans-unit.target: Only empty partitions can be split in when a columnstore index exists on the table.

trans-unit.source: Consider disabling the columnstore index before issuing the ALTER PARTITION statement, then rebuilding the columnstore index after ALTER PARTITION is complete.
trans-unit.target: Consider disabling the columnstore index before issuing the ALTER PARTITION statement, then rebuilding the columnstore index after ALTER PARTITION is complete.

trans-unit.source: However we can use CTAS to create a new table to hold our data.
trans-unit.target: However we can use CTAS to create a new table to hold our data.

trans-unit.source: As the partition boundaries are aligned a switch is permitted.
trans-unit.target: As the partition boundaries are aligned a switch is permitted.

trans-unit.source: This will leave the source table with an empty partition that we can subsequently split.
trans-unit.target: This will leave the source table with an empty partition that we can subsequently split.

trans-unit.source: All that is left to do is to align our data to the new partition boundaries using CTAS and switch our data back in to the main table
trans-unit.target: All that is left to do is to align our data to the new partition boundaries using CTAS and switch our data back in to the main table

trans-unit.source: Once you have completed the movement of the data it is a good idea to refresh the statistics on the target table to ensure they accurately reflect the new distribution of the data in their respective partitions:
trans-unit.target: Once you have completed the movement of the data it is a good idea to refresh the statistics on the target table to ensure they accurately reflect the new distribution of the data in their respective partitions:

trans-unit.source: To avoid your table definition from rusting in your source control system you may want to consider the following approach:
trans-unit.target: To avoid your table definition from rusting in your source control system you may want to consider the following approach:

trans-unit.source: Create the table as a partitioned table but with no partition values
trans-unit.target: Create the table as a partitioned table but with no partition values

trans-unit.source: SPLIT the table as part of the deployment process:
trans-unit.target: SPLIT the table as part of the deployment process:

trans-unit.source: With this approach the code in source control remains static and the partitioning boundary values are allowed to be dynamic; evolving with the warehouse over time.
trans-unit.target: With this approach the code in source control remains static and the partitioning boundary values are allowed to be dynamic; evolving with the warehouse over time.

trans-unit.source: Partition switching has a few differences in comparison to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Partition switching has a few differences in comparison to SQL Server.

trans-unit.target: Be sure to read <linkText>Migrate your code</linkText><title></title> to learn more about this subject.
